reviewText:
One of the best TD games out there! Great, colorful graphics and animation, high polish!

Lets see about those towers! 4 towers, 3 upgrades each and 2 Ultimate" upgrade choices for each tower. And every Ultimate tower has at least 2 abilities that you can purchase! To give an example: the Archer tower shoots rapidly at land or air targets and has a good range. Every upgrade increases range and damage and upon reaching Ultimate level you can choose to turn it into a Ranger tower or a Sharpshooter tower! The Ranger tower has Roots  that can AoE stun and damage many enemies around it and Poison Arrows that deal a potent DoT to whatever they hit. The Sharpshooter tower has the longest range in the game and gets Headshot that deals massive damage or outright 1-hit KOs an enemy and Shrapnel Blast that deals massive AoE damage.

Thats just the Archer tower! The other 3 tower types all have their upgrades and 2 Ultimate tower choices!

Now
date: we also have to talk about the Barracks towers. Kingdom Rush was pretty much the pioneer of the barracks type towers in which actual squads of soldiers will come out of them and stand on the creep paths. These soldiers will then block/stop enemies from moving while they do battle! You can
hoursPlayed: choose where the squads will gather to protect certain parts of the path! The soldiers have their own hitpoints
voteText: damage and once upgarded to their Ultimate forms they can gain all sorts of special attacks and defensive abilities!\n\nThe enemies are also increadibly varied and Kingdrom Rush sports some of the most interesting enemy types out there. Seriously
helpfulPercent:
they send a new type of enemy at you on almost EVERY single level. Every 5 or so levels you'll get a boss battle and ooooh boy some of them are pretty intense.

You also get special Heroes that you unlock as you progress through the campaign and they each have at least 2 special abilites. For example Alera Windrunner summons a tanky sabrecat and has a multishot ability that fires 4-5 arrows at groups of enemies. Heroes can level up to 10 in every battle and will do more damage and power up their abilites. You can freely move them about the battlefield to help out where its most needed!

Whew
votesTotal: don't want to make this much longer so I'll just say that if you like TD games you really can't go wrong with Kingdom Rush unless you absolutely have to have tower mazing - of which their is none in Kingdom Rush. The Steam version comes with all DLC unlocked and will be strongly supported by the devs with new content and goodies!"

reviewText: First found this little gem on Newgrounds.com. Played it almost to completion then. Kingdom Rush is the best tower defense game out there. It has beautiful graphics, nice music and sound effects, an intuitive UI and more than enough content to justify the pricetag. Many complain that the game is available for free as a flash game on certain websites. This version has alot more content than the free version and buying here supports the developers that deserve your money. My only complaint is that two more have released and they havent found their way on to Steam. Hey Ironhide, show us some love too. If you are worried that the game just doesnt have enough depth to hold your attention very long, consider this. There are loads of levels, lots of unlockable heroes, a skill tree with tons of skills and more. The game was also updated recently with more heroes and another campaign. There really is no negative I can level against this game. If you enjoy tower defense games, buy it.

reviewText:
Played it back in the days when Online Flash Games were a hit and it was awesome! I wouldn't suggest buying this game at full price but when the sale hits, its a must BUY! Its damn epic and fun as well as challenging with unlockables and upgrades available to unlock in which ever order you wish. It will take you multiple hours for you to finish and some hard time progressing at higher diff which is worth it. If you love TowerDefense games then its a must get, just place it in your wishlist and when it goes on sale buy it.
You can either go full melee, archery; artillery or magick dmg which sometimes results in its own ups and downs meaning you will need to do it over an dover untill you master it and are skilled enough to proceed.
Casual gaming nothing hardcore.

reviewText:
I loved Kingdom Rush As A Kid. It was a fantasy tower defence game and it started out as a Flash game and later on it camed to app and to Steam. Steam is a little bit better than Flash because it had more levels and towers were fixed. The game had memorable enemies, memorable towers, good Music, allot of refences (like Bombardiers said Hail To The King Baby) and also had Landskapes that fit well with fantasy. The Villian Vez´nan is a stereotypical villian but i still loved him, i mean he doesnt do anything and sends his enemies but my good his a fan Of Many Villians and Dark side users. His the icon of the entire Kingdom Rush Series and had many appearances in other video games like ToToTemple. You can also get steam cards wich has only 5 cards to make a stamp. Big bertha is my favorite tower not because it has Rockets and looks better than tesla its because it wrecked the entire enemies and i use tesla when dealing with Hordes of enemies but most of the time you need to use Tesla.

Pros
+Good level design
+Good music
+Memorable enemies
+Steam Cards
+Towers are great
+Even More Memorable Villian Vez´nan
+Good graphics
+Funny
+You can fully complete the entire Achievements

Cons
-Heroes (the only best heroes out there are Oni, Hacksaw and Elonora)
-Some towers are overpowered like Sorcerers and Tesla
-Some towers are least used like Big Bertha and Musketeers
-Early levels music is pretty bland

Thats all to say but ill have to say Its actualy my opinion the best tower defence game of all time and later on theres gonna be a sequel. Ill give it 5/5

reviewText: A magnificant example of the genre. Easy to learn, tought to master, like chess. This game is polished to a shine, and balanced to perfection. Being a big fan of Tower Defense games, balance is always an issue for me. Not so here. Everything has been carefully weighed and priced (via gold to buy towers) to make it seem tough but fair. The early levels teach you everything, and it slowly escelates into an all-out rage-war that will leave you screaming and hitting the try again" button because you were so close to winning that time. Its addictive
date: has a steady (though unforgiving near the end) learning curve
recommended: and the boss characters that show up are just amazing. Its packed with easter eggs (perhaps a few too many
hoursPlayed: each tower has recognizable lines and there are things hidden on EVERY map)
voteText: good dialogue and excellent voice acting. You even unlock more levels when the campaign is over. Worth every penny of my mere $10 that I had to pay to get it. Two thumbs WAY way up

reviewText:
I'd recommend anyone who is interested in tower defense games such as this title.

I've played Kingdom Rush 1 when it was released on Armor Games back then, then was made available at Kongregate. Also played Kingdom Rush 2 on my smartphone, very impressed that I have yet to experience any lag. Then, played KR2 on Kongregate. Seeing that KR has been released on Steam, I would support them because they have yet to disappoint me. Though, to unlock more heroes and other bonuses, you had to pay through microtransactions. This game here on steam eliminates all of that.

Art style is nice, sprite animation is great & seamless, and the colors are easy on the eyes. For $7.50 w/ a -25% discount, it's a steal. I'd still pay the full amount for the content and hours I've placed in the game.

reviewText:
What can I say about this game other than its fantastic. The version created for steam trumps the iOS version by far, with no additional costs for heroes, premium content or microtransactions, if you're a TD type of person or ever thought you wanted to give it a try, the Steam version of Kingdom Rush is for you.

Let me begin on the first day I was introduced to the flash version of this game I ended up being hooked. It was so easy to get into, gave me hours of entertainment and laughs and even some aggrivation whilst trying to figure out how to complete each level with 3 stars. By the time I had finished the original campaign mode of the 12 levels, I couldn't believe that a game such as this one, with the graphics, gameplay, voice acting, music score and overall enjoyability, was free! I felt like it should've been worth something!

Which is what happened with the iOS version. However... I'm not a fan of purchasing a game only to have a ton of microtransactions needed for the full experience. Premium content wasn't included, no heroes etc. That wasn't a good way to go about it in my books at least. Left much to be desired...

That is why the day it released on steam I had no reservations or hesitation on buying it and diving right back into it. Now it included all the premuim content and all the heroes and has a promise of more to come ontop of that!

The Steam version's gameplay is smooth and enjoyable. I only had one hiccough on an Iron Challenge level with a certain enemy getting stuck on the edge of the map for a few attempts. The issue eventually resolved itself, but Iron Hide has been very good about providing bug fixes to this game in a timely matter so I expect that'll be fixed over soon.

The graphics for this game are fantastic! Each level has its own attention to detail, the NPC's and enemy's movements are smooth and while some might argue the cartoonish animation is childish and unappealing, I beg to differ! I absolutely love it!

The sound in this game is amazing! The music in this game is simply stellar. It brings the right amount of emotion to each level. When I hear the boss music que up, I always felt my pulse quicken and the sense of urgency rise as if I needed to pump up my offense and defense and quickly! Any game thats able to do that with a simple musical score is worth your time to look at. Not to mention the voice acting! I nearly died the first day I upgraded my Dwarven artillery to the Big Bertha, added a rocket only to hear Yippie Kai-yay mother *BEEP"! I remember going out of my way to upgrade my dwarven towers just to be able to hear that one line over and over. And still to this day I get a giggle out of it.

I just finished this game 100% now on all levels and I couldn't be happier with my purchase. I had hours
date: hours of enjoyment! And I will definitely play it again and again
recommended: not just because I want to see how I could complete each level with different strategies
hoursPlayed: but because it is simply fun!\n\nSo granted there are some bugs with the game so far
voteText: the purchase price of 10 bucks is so worth it! I mean

votesTotal: great acting... you can't get much better than that!"

reviewText: I loved playing tower defence when it was first invented in the custom maps in warcraft and starcraft. Each level in this game takes about 15 - 20 minutes to complete (assuming you make it to the end!), making it perfect for the casual gamer whos not afraid of a bit of strategy. I was pleasantly supprised with the added bonus levels which are awarded to you after you beat the main campaign. These extra levels, have a considerable higher difficulty, which really get you planning out your builds, and aniticipating whats to come in the next wave. There are also 2 extra challenge modes for each level, which really do add to the replayability to them. I really like this game, (and most well done tower defence games) which is why I bought it during its release sale at $7.50. Even at sale price, the amount does seem a little high for this game, but, for me, it was worth it. For those who are not as TD and strategy savvy as I, I'm sure there will be a better price on this game in the future. I think $5 is fully justified for this game.

reviewText:
What can I say about this game other than its fantastic. The version created for steam trumps the iOS version by far, with no additional costs for heroes, premium content or microtransactions, if you're a TD type of person or ever thought you wanted to give it a try, the Steam version of Kingdom Rush is for you.

Let me begin on the first day I was introduced to the flash version of this game I ended up being hooked. It was so easy to get into, gave me hours of entertainment and laughs and even some aggrivation whilst trying to figure out how to complete each level with 3 stars. By the time I had finished the original campaign mode of the 12 levels, I couldn't believe that a game such as this one, with the graphics, gameplay, voice acting, music score and overall enjoyability, was free! I felt like it should've been worth something!

Which is what happened with the iOS version. However... I'm not a fan of purchasing a game only to have a ton of microtransactions needed for the full experience. Premium content wasn't included, no heroes etc. That wasn't a good way to go about it in my books at least. Left much to be desired...

That is why the day it released on steam I had no reservations or hesitation on buying it and diving right back into it. Now it included all the premuim content and all the heroes and has a promise of more to come ontop of that!

The Steam version's gameplay is smooth and enjoyable. I only had one hiccough on an Iron Challenge level with a certain enemy getting stuck on the edge of the map for a few attempts. The issue eventually resolved itself, but Iron Hide has been very good about providing bug fixes to this game in a timely matter so I expect that'll be fixed over soon.

The graphics for this game are fantastic! Each level has its own attention to detail, the NPC's and enemy's movements are smooth and while some might argue the cartoonish animation is childish and unappealing, I beg to differ! I absolutely love it!

The sound in this game is amazing! The music in this game is simply stellar. It brings the right amount of emotion to each level. When I hear the boss music que up, I always felt my pulse quicken and the sense of urgency rise as if I needed to pump up my offense and defense and quickly! Any game thats able to do that with a simple musical score is worth your time to look at. Not to mention the voice acting! I nearly died the first day I upgraded my Dwarven artillery to the Big Bertha, added a rocket only to hear Yippie Kai-yay mother *BEEP"! I remember going out of my way to upgrade my dwarven towers just to be able to hear that one line over and over. And still to this day I get a giggle out of it.

I just finished this game 100% now on all levels and I couldn't be happier with my purchase. I had hours
date: hours of enjoyment! And I will definitely play it again and again
recommended: not just because I want to see how I could complete each level with different strategies
hoursPlayed: but because it is simply fun!\n\nSo granted there are some bugs with the game so far
voteText: the purchase price of 10 bucks is so worth it! I mean
helpfulPercent: there are so many people who are willing to throw 50 bucks or more out the window for games that are absolute garbage and here you have the chance to get a great game with high replay value for 10 bucks! It has great graphics
votesTotal: great acting... you can't get much better than that!"

reviewText: Kingdom Rush is the best game I've ever played on my iPhone. If you've never played Kingdom Rush, I would recommend getting it for your phone when it's on sale. However, if you don't have that option or would rather play on a PC, then this is still a great game.\n\nI prefer it on phone, despite the paid content, because I think the balance is better. Since all the additional content is included in the PC version, they had to mess with unit attributes to prevent overpowering units from breaking the game. That said, if you thought the phone version was too easy at times, or if you want to experience the paid phone content, you might prefer the PC version.

reviewText:
Probably one of the best, if not THE best tower defense series I've ever played.  Unfortunately they only have this one on Steam, but they have two more available, a prequel and a sequel available on the mobile Android OS.

Works a bit like your standard TD game, however you have heroes that you fight with in battles with ranging classes, as well as a skilltree that you earn points/stars for as you progress through the campaign.  These talents buff either your towers, reinforcements, or spells.

This game has good graphics for being a mobile port, easy controls, a nice UI, excellent replayability, and most importantly it's tons of fun.  I would highly recommend any game in this series both here on Steam and on mobile, I actually just bought the prequel yesterday.

(I actually like the prequel a bit more, even though it's a lot harder.)

reviewText:
Pretty proud to say that I'm a huge fan of Armor Games, and of course Kingdom Rush is THE most amazing flash game that I've ever played and I have been through its many earlier versions. And finally I'm more than happy to see its successul conversion from the original flash version which was only around 20MB's large.

Although there are certain minor imperfections(such as removing in-battle encyclopedia and some controlling incovniences), the game yet has(again) blown me away. Hopefully it'll be improved with the next few updates.

Uniquely cartoonish art style with bright colors, intense but untiring music, and all those lines and quotes always keep you entertained in its easy, funny way. Not to mention the stratigic battles and the hilarious animations!

If you are a fan of TD games and haven't tried Kingdom Rush -- you are really missing out. You are so guaranteed that you will love it.
And even if you are not really into TD games, you may as well try out this PC version of the over 49 million times of play and 9.7/10 scored little game.

Thanks. Alway have fun.
: )

reviewText: Kingdom Rush is one of those rare games that I just never tire of.  The art, the sound, the gameplay, the style, all of it just works so perfectly that you forget that you have been playing this game for three hours and you need to go do something productive. I played through this game three times now, once on iPad, once on Nexus 7, and once on iPhone, and it still remains fun. It has the style of PvZ with the variety of other TD games like Bloons and Fieldrunners. I highly reccomend this for anyone who likes Tower Defense games. Enjoy!

reviewText:
Pretty proud to say that I'm a huge fan of Armor Games, and of course Kingdom Rush is THE most amazing flash game that I've ever played and I have been through its many earlier versions. And finally I'm more than happy to see its successul conversion from the original flash version which was only around 20MB's large.

Although there are certain minor imperfections(such as removing in-battle encyclopedia and some controlling incovniences), the game yet has(again) blown me away. Hopefully it'll be improved with the next few updates.

Uniquely cartoonish art style with bright colors, intense but untiring music, and all those lines and quotes always keep you entertained in its easy, funny way. Not to mention the stratigic battles and the hilarious animations!

If you are a fan of TD games and haven't tried Kingdom Rush -- you are really missing out. You are so guaranteed that you will love it.
And even if you are not really into TD games, you may as well try out this PC version of the over 49 million times of play and 9.7/10 scored little game.

Thanks. Alway have fun.
: )

reviewText:
EDIT:  Turns out Ironhide isn't making anymore PC games.  Until this changes, I simply cannot reccommend buying a game from a company that continues to profit off a player base that it will not make games for (they turned to the mobile market instead).

Original review:

Let's put everything out in front of us.  This game is free online.  What isn't online though?  Extra heroes, extra levels, and this game right at your fingertips.  I loved playing this online.  It was and is a fun game.  I've never unistalled it to make way for new games, nor have I ever regretted the purchase.

This game was worth the buy.  It has interesting levels which all can be beat in different ways.  It's a tower defense game with a twist; there is one lane and an extremely diverse amount of units.  The game weans you into the difficult levels as well.  Little by little it allows you to unlock all the towers, all the heroes, all the enemies, etc.  Each level also has an Iron Challenge" (build any towers with one continuous wave of enemies)
date: and a "Heroic Challenge" (one continuous wave of enemies while not being able to build certain towers).  Basically
recommended: this game can be as easy or strategic as you want it to be.\n\nSo why Kingdom Rush?  Because of the choice of towers.  You have Arrow towers (which do basic damage as a medium speed)
hoursPlayed: Mage towers (which bypass armor
voteText: do better damage
helpfulPercent: but not as quick)
votesHelpful: Bomb towers (which do basic damage in an area with a slow speed)
votesTotal: and Soldier barracks (three melee units strum out to stop enemies in their paths and fight them head on).  Each tower upgrades twice.\n\nHowever
votesFunny: it doesn't stop there.  Each tower also has two different third upgrades to go into.  The Archer towers become either Forest Elves (shoot super fast and have poison attacks and can strangle enemies in place with vines) or Gun Towers (slow but extremely powerful and far reaching snipers that can take down most minions in one shot).\n\nThe Mage towers become towers of Support (slows enemies
commentsCount: spawns golems to fight for you
column16: or turns enemies into literal sheep) or towers of Death (transports enemies back in line or can insta-kill enemies with extremely powerful magic beams).\n\nBomb towers turn into Rocket Launchers (can do mass aoe damage
column17: spawns homing rockets
column18: and secondary multiple missile shells) or Electric Turbines (can chain lightning enemies
column19:
do aoe attacks from the base of the turbine).

And Soldiers can eventually upgrade into Holy Knights (which can do smites and heal themselves) or Barbarians (which can eventually dual wield axes and become ranged throwers as well).

Buy this game.  No ragrets."

reviewText: I didn't have the chance to play this game on smartphones neither on tablets before, so, reading all the positive reviews i decided to give it a try. It's a very classic tower defense game built with touch screen interface in mind: this means it is a very limited interactive game. You just click like an housewife on the already defined towers spawn points and chose the kind of tower you want to deploy. Basically that's all about it's gameplay, excluding some abilities that you have the chance to use every bunch of seconds just clicking on the point you want to fire them. All the new units unlock is automatic and you have just the chance to select wich branch of towers you want to upgrade first (either in the skill three and during the monster waves). The heroes are just the same: you get them automatically while the game progresses and you click on them in order to move'em towards the spot you want them to help defending.  It doesn't mean the game isn't funny or even challenging, but that, in my opinion , limited interactive games like this are best suited for touchscreens and that there, in that very market segment they should remain. At this price tag, Revenge of the Titans, Defender's Quest or Anomaly IMO are much better choices for some PC tower defence pleasure.

reviewText:
This is NOT a good tower defense game. Just compare a few pieces to any other decent TD game:
Does it have pathing? No
Can you win later levels (or even early ones) on the basis of your tower (defence) alone? No
Does it require intense micromanaging on most (and especially later) levels? Absolutely
Are there levels where there is essentially only one way to win? Yep
Are there very obvious holdover elements from its mobile roots? TAP TO UNFREEEEZE TAP! TAP! TAP!

It puts on a good front, it looks cutesy, the barrier to entry (during a sale) is pretty low, and there's lots of easy to get achievements. What you will miss out on if you play this versus another, more polished tower defence game, like Defence Grid or Anomaly, is FUN. Also, a lot of the core mechanics that have made TD games less of a chore and more of a puzzle. Go buy one of those instead.
voteText: 4 of 13 people (31%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
As a tower defense game, this is one of the better ones out there. Unfortunately, this is the exact same version that you can play for free on android/ios or on various game websites. Don't get this game on Steam, go play it somewhere else, there is no added value here (unless achievements and trading cards are worth $10 to you). At least I got it as part of a bundle so I didn't have to pay full price for it. This is the reason I'm not recommending it, not because the game itself is necessarily that bad but more because this version is a grossly overpriced mobile port, not a real PC game.

As for the game itself, despite being one of the better tower defense games, it still has some issues. The biggest one being that this game frequently degenerates into a mad click-fest which I don't particularly like, for me I like tower defense games that give you some time to think and plan things out between waves and that give more flexibility in terms of tower placement. This game limits you to existing tower plots on the map, severely limiting what you can do with your towers.
These issues aren't even really inherent to a mobile game, bloons tower defense does a much better job in terms of tower variety, placement flexibility and planning between waves (even if the enemy types are boring).

Still, this game is a fun little time waster, but if you want a great PC tower defense game, go look at Orcs Must Die or Sanctum. They're cheaper and far better.

reviewText: Well, it started off as a good game BUT there are improvements that need to be made for sure. The selection controls are absolutely HORRIBLE. Very bad. Selecting your hero at times is just plain frustrating (play it to mid game and you'll see what I'm saying). Going from hero selection to structure (or vice versa) is equally frustrating. It definitely does NOT have smooth controls. I am curious how such an oversight skipped testing. Did the developers not play the game? Also, the hero and footman AI are pretty bad. Your unit can be standing right next to an enemy creep and he won't attack simply because it is not on the same horizontal plane, even though they're pretty much touching. In short, this is a decent game that could have been great. It has some rather big flaws that makes the game a bit frustrating. I would say my stance on this game is neutral but as there is no neutral selection I am choosing No" for recommendation."

reviewText:
FIrst i'll say I love this game. It is an interesting, unique take on tower defense with lots of fun to be had. However I can't recommend this to anyone for a lot of reasons.

First of all it's a mobile game that was ported to PC and it was ported very poorly. It is riddled with a lot of little bugs that hurt your ability to play the game on PC. One example is the poisoned arrows upgrade for ranger towers should always prioritize non-poisoned targets over poisoned ones, and should also prioritize targets that CAN be poisoned over targets that are immune. Well, they don't in the PC version. This bug has existed since release and was never fixed. It changes your strategy for dealing with some things because on the mobile version when it's working perfectly the poison upgrade makes the tower shoot necromancers only, ignoring the skeleton swarms around them, to kill them off so they stop summoning more. In the buggy, broken PC version they shoot skeletons and the skeletons are immune to poison altogether.

Second, it is unsupported. It will never have any of it's bugs fixed, it will never have any additional content added. The developers used this as a one-time cash grab and now they have washed their hands of steam altogether. The mobile version has an endless mode where you can just go wave after wave until you're defeated and let you try to get on the leaderboard for having the best strategy. PC version didn't deserve this feature in any form. Very disappointing since it's the most fun part of the game on mobile after you finish" it.

Third
date: you can play this game for free in flash online on many different websites. The flash version has 3 of the heroes in this version
recommended: but allows you to purchase additional heroes for money. However these additional heroes are entirely not needed
hoursPlayed: the ones you are given for free are more than enough to complete the game on the hardest difficulty in every mode. This version only has about 7 or 8 levels that the completely free version doesn't have
voteText: and again
helpfulPercent: you can purchase those bonus levels if you desire.\n\nDespite playing the flash version
votesHelpful: when I saw this on steam I bought it up quickly because I loved the game and thought I was buying something worth buying. But after the fact I found out they won't be fixing any of the bugs

reviewText:
Kingdom Rush is a flash-style tower defense game that has been around for a while on sites such as kongregate.com, miniclip.com, or armorgames.com. While it has high quality for a browser game, I think it should have stayed there.

Plot 5/10

You are a nameless general that is saving a kingdom from eeeeeviiil. It's not that bad, but not good, either. The purpose is served well enough. Won't rag on this.

Sound 9/10

The sounds are terrific, and fit everything very well. They also add to the game's visual style. The voices probably steal the show on this game, though. They're corny, over-acted sometimes, but always funny, distinct, and fun. KR also has comedic references to other media including Portal, Half-Life, Star Wars, Die Hard, the Bible, and many others. The sound is KR's pride with the exception of the music. While entertaining, there's about 3 tracks that last 30s long and are set to loop. It just could have been a bit better.

Graphics 10/10

The graphics too are wonderful, colorful, and stylish. Visually the game isn't too flashy, which is good because it clears up visual clutter. With so many things moving on screen at once, the visuals organize everything to give the player what they need to see. Enemies are fun and recognizable. KR's visuals are spot-on. Bull's-eye.

Gameplay 10/10

With the barrage of tower defense games out there, it's easy to get weary of the grind. KR however, brings much, much needed personality and freshness that this crowded genre so direly needed. You place towers that are immune to enemies, and auto-attack the enemies. Placing a barracks trains 3 infantry to stop up to 3 passing enemies allowing your damage towers to wittle them down. The infantry can die, though, and have a respawn time. Some enemies have armor and are weak to magic, while others have magic resistance and low armor. Towers can be upgraded for more damage, alternate attack styles, and different personalities from the crew. It all works wonderfully and the game gets REALLY challenging fast. It works so well, KR is a high standard on how tower defense games should be made. It's that good.

The Verdict

Everything's so good
date: so why do you not recommend it?" Good question: the only con is the game is waaaay too short. Once you get half-decent at it
recommended: you will BLAST your way through the campaign (and most side missions) in about an hour. The game has high quality
hoursPlayed: but is far

reviewText:
Can not recommend this game, because for some players this is not even a game. This is a non working executable. First time (after years and more than a houndred steam apps) of having something not work for me in steam.

TLDR: Tried everything, including official support, no response from their team. Payed $10 to have nothing. Absolutely nothing.

Starting configuration menu is invisible. Can press enter to play, but the game crashes upon loading the first level. Tried reinstalling video drivers, windows redistributables, verifying integrity of game cache.
Was lured by pretty videos, but can not recommend an unstable game. What's happening 6 months after steam release (and an expansion after)? They require you to send crash logs, because they think content > stability. Way to go, ironhide.

Besides all the steps detailed, after more than a week and instructions in the forum sticky, still no response from their tech support.

Edit: Many months have passed and still no response, though the game works now. Game is about 3/5, with customer support 0/5.

reviewText:
I play a lot of TD games. I love TD and strategy games.

This game is like babies first TD. It has 4 possible towers and all the positions for tower placements are made for you.

There is an archer tower which fires fast but does light damage, mage tower which pirces armor units, siege towers which do aoe splash, and barracks which produce units to block creeps.

There is no slow towers so you have to rely on barracks to block creeps so your other towers can do something. Barracks only spawn 3 units so if there are more than 3 creeps coming then they will walk on by. The siege towers are useless because of the lack of slow. There is no point in aoe in this game. The mage towers are also lacking since they are much slower than the archers and armored units are few and far between. The strategy is reduced to spaming archer towers and barracks. Pretty boring.

It does have hero units ala some Warcraft 3 td maps but you bearly control it. You tell it where to stand and it does everything else on its own.

You have 2 hero powers. One to spawn 2 units and the other to summon a small firestorm. Both of these powers quickly become useless unless you upgrade them. However, upgrading them means you arent upgrading your towers which makes it stupid.

The story is nothing to talk about. Its toled through about 2 sentences before every mission. Throw away.

All in all this TD is extremly basic and really shows its mobile origin. If you love TDs you might be ok picking it up on sale for a buck but otherwise leave it be.

reviewText:
For $7 this was fun enough. Over 5 hours of playing until I tried the same sorry arsed level 15 times. Ridiculously hard. Maybe if you do things in exactly the right order of placing, upgrading, and selecting the right hero then you could beat it. maybe. Not fun enough to try all the combinations though so I'll move along. Setting difficulty to easy is not an option.

I am changing my review to not recommended. I lowered difficulty to casual and it is still extremely difficult. There are just so many enemies that you get overrun. Some come out of unmarked areas with nearly no mount points for defense buildings. Breakdown:

Graphics: Great for this type of game, no complaint
Sound:  Good for this type of game, not much on sound anyway
Mechanics: Things work well, do not appear to be any bugs or issues
Level Design: Overall pretty good, but unmarked areas that spawn unexpected mobs is a big NO
Buildings: Good mix of abilities, being limited on where you can place a building is terrible
Heroes: Somewhat helpful but too much babysitting that distracts from elsewhere
Miscellaneous: Absolutely aggravating is having to click 2-3 times on a 'disabled' building

It could be an excellent game if a few points above were addressed, but there is something irritating having to try 10 to 20 times to beat a level to advance. Add in the clicking crap and building placement limitations and I really can't recommend it. However if you get it for around $5 it is fun for awhile.

Marginal 5/10 and thumbs down

reviewText: The mobile version of this is far superior.  They've taken the microtransactions out of the original game(Frontiers still has them) and the ability to earn the gems as you play to get useful items to make the harder levels more manageable is nice.  Something on top to earn even if you don't perfect a level.  The PC version not only lacks these(I can't imagine trying some of the endgame bonus levels on hard without at least one extra gold bag to start me off with or an ice wand), but it also has frankly unacceptable load times, with the average for me being 45 seconds or so.  Which is ridiculous for a glorified flash game/mobile game on a pretty strong PC.  Being able to hotkey reinforcements and such is a plus, but it doesn't outweigh the handiness of the touchscreen.  I made it a bit over halfway through the campaign before deciding the PC version's not my thing.\n\nGet the mobile version.  IOS or Android, either one is fantastic.  I would recommend not getting this on PC though.

reviewText:
Firstly this game is available free to play as a browser game which I had been playing for many a year, and did not even realise this game was on steam untill recived as part of an indie bundle.

If you like tower defence games and are unsure about buying this then check out the browser version, as to be honest differences between the browser version and the steam version are not worth the £6.99 asking price. If however you can get it for £1.99 or less then I would recomend it.

Sadly with the steam version they missed a trick,it lacks replayability due to the lack of any kind of scoreboard. Dueing missions you get 1 to 3 stars based on performance and thats it, the only replayability is to get 3 stars in each mission, I just wish they had something like in defence grid with a score based on time / unspent gold / lives remaining etc etc or something simlar to give reason to reply the game.

With 3 stars up for grabs each level with a max obtainable of 120 thats 40 levels and in 80 ish minuites i've completed 10  and thats with some afk time.

The level deigns / layouts are good, the towers while they may seem limited in variety have intresting upgrades that completely change what they do, so why it may seem there are only 4 different towers theres more like 16.

I'm not going to go into any more depth about the game as it is avail for free to play and within 30 mins play you will get to see most of which is on offer and if you like it and its cheap then buy it for the trading cards and chevos on steam.

It is a good game but based on the fact its short, lacks replayability and is avail to play free as a browser game I can not reccomend this game to buy at its current asking place.

If you want some free tower defence goodness checkout cursed treasure, gem craft and desktop tower defence. All are fine games.

reviewText: If you've played the iPhone/iPad game, this one is very similar. They've changed a lot of things, specifically the heroes are pretty different. The heroes in the version are all different, and you cant actually upgrade them. You just choose one and position it around the map. This kind of change was carried over to all parts of the game I feel. Most in-game tower upgrades are ineffectual, as are the out-of-game upgrades you spend points to unlock. I never felt like anything I did made my game any different from anyone elses. This would would have been fine if thats the kind of experience they were aiming for, but based on its predessor, and how many different methods they have the potential to allow customization in, it seems more like a badly executed RPG system, not a well balanced even-playing field kind of thing.

reviewText:
Tower defense games are my preferred game style for the last few years.  Many developers have tried to come into the space and capture the experience but Ironhide Game Studios has set the bar to epic with Kingdom Rush.

I have purchased this game for iPhone, iPad and for the PC and have done a full play through almost 4 times (once for each platform, twice on the iPad).  The PC version sports a few differences that are worth mentioning if you already have played through on the iOS.

PC differences of note:
1) There is no more collecting crystals during in-game play for purchasing extras" for use during levels.  On the PC you have what you are able to do during the level and that is it.
2) There is no difficultly settings to play with.  On IOS there is Normal and Hard mode; PC allows no selection.
3) On PC you have open access to all of the heroes; no need to purchase them as you did on the IOS versions.

If you are a fan of any Tower Defense games and would like to explore the genre a bit more
date: Kingdom Rush is a very easy recommendation and carries with it quite a bit of replayability.  Go forth and defend the kingdom!"

reviewText:
Okay, the game isnt complex, but its the most fun I had for less than £3! I wont bore you with the gameplay but basically you use three keys to play the game and you then die in lava. But you then get to upgrade and then try again. Then die in lava. But then upgrade some more and try again and get even further than last time and then you die in lava. Then you upgrade and you try again etc...
I intended to only spend half an hour playing this game before hitting the hay. I looked at the time 30mins later only to find that TWO HOURS had passed!
Any game that can make you lose your track of time because you are enjoying it gets a great big thumbs up from me! Highly Recommended little game.
Just make sure to keep an eye on the clock. Its so easy to say one more try...""

reviewText: One of the best flash based TD games out there, if not the BEST in my opinion. There's a lengthy campaign and different challenges to help with replay value. It has been out on mobile devices since a couple of years ago. Having completed it on mobile, there's not much motivation to replay it again except to enjoy it on a bigger screen. It is also nicer to look at with the updated UI and graphics. Kudos to Ironhide Game Studio for still supporting the game with FREE content updates even after it's release 3 years ago, more content are coming in the future. All in-app transactions have been completely removed and contents can be unlocked just by playing the game, so the price is justifiable.\n\n8/10

reviewText:
One of the best tower defence games i've played.

Charming graphics, funny speech and sounds, very strategic. You build towers in preset locations using money, which you get by killing enemies. While battling, you upgrade said towers again using money. After every succesful battle you are awarded up to three stars each mission, which you use to unlock perks for your towers and these perks are well thought out, offering many gamechanging mechanics and -ofcourse- more damage.

All towers are equally useful: magic for strong/armored enemies, bombs for crowds, archers for small & fast enemies, soldiers for stoping & gathering enemies. You also have 2 special powers which have a cooldown and can be used indefinately (1.inserting 2  soldiers anywhere you want and 2. meteor shower). By the way, special powers get perks too.

And then there are heroes"
date: which are directly controled by the player
recommended: have special powers and suit many different playstyles (strong melee
hoursPlayed: weak magic
voteText: ranged
helpfulPercent: teleporting among others). Between heroes
votesHelpful: special powers and the fact that you can demolish your own towers (and get a little refund) to build a different towers in their place
votesTotal: you will never feel powerless or blame the game.\n\nMake no mistake though
votesFunny: the game becomes gradually challenging. You won't be needing lightning reflexes
commentsCount: but you'll have to learn by trial and error sometimes. If you are easily frustrated
column16: there's always the "casual" difficulty setting.\n\nAs for longevity
column17: this game is a completionist's dream. Beat the main campaign and you still have 2 challenges for each mission (which restrict what types of units and level of upgrades you can use - for me these were even more fun than the main mission!) and a couple random missions poping up all over the map. I haven't completed everything yet
column18: but i'd say you're getting at least 20 hours of fun.\n\nWell worth the price."

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I've played the free version of this game on ArmorGames.com, the retail version on Steam is well worth the money for the extra levels and features.

In addtional to the usualy upgradable towers and fixed path that enemies travel through, you have a combination of global abilities (reinforcements and a pinpoint strike attack, both with regular cooldown times), plus you get to manage a single hero character that roams around the map at will.  Between strategizing your tower builds, timing your abilities and micromanaging your hero, you'll be kept very busy on every level!

The replayability comes from the enticement to collect the achievements, which in turn also earns you stars to get passive upgrades on your towers, which in turn are required to conquer later levels as well.

If you are a fan of the tower defense genre of games, you're going to enjoy playing Kingdom Rush immensely!

reviewText:
If you are a tower defence fan then Kingdom Rush is one you should certainly not miss.
It’s a cute looking game with many additions to the traditional tower defence model that add a lot of depth.
The big thing about the game is that, it’s busier then your regular tower defence because you have a hero character to manage and defence points to alter by moving around the location where your units hold the front.
Of course there are plenty of different towers and upgrades and a plethora of various enemies of unique characteristics.
Sound design is decent, graphics are cute, and mechanics are solid. There is a bit of storyline there as well but nothing to write home about. Just a great tower defence experience.
8/10

reviewText: Kingdom Rush is, without a doubt, the second best classic-style Tower Defense game out there. The first being the Defense Grid series, of course. That said, if you own Defense Grid (or not) you deserve to give Kingdom Rush a chance anyway.\n\nStarting out as a portable game on iOS and Android, I half expected the PC version to just be a cheap port. Oh man was I wrong! Graphics are subtly improved, while not loosing their style. The map view is way better on the PC version. The difficulty has been upped, to force you to plan better. Even mouse effects have been added when you're casting your fireball" and "reinforce" skills. The game actually feels as if it was made for the PC
date: and that's how game ports should be!\n\nThe graphics for Kingdom Rush are different and unique. You'll absolutely love them. The tower upgrades are also VERY well done
recommended: with each upgrade changing both the look of the "tower" and the "units" it supports. While not really that dissimilar from the portable version
hoursPlayed: it does make viewing the game on 24+ inch screens a delightful experience.\n\nGamev play is the biggest surprise here
voteText: because this isn't any ordinary tower defense game. There's also a bit of RTS involved. For example
helpfulPercent: when you put down a "soldier" tower (which spawns 3 soldiers) you can set a relay flag within the radius of the tower's influence. This allows you to put many towers in close proximity
votesHelpful: rallying them at the same spot to form an army
votesTotal: or have your tower in the vicinity of multiple paths so you can adjust your raly deployments to whichever path needs it at the time. Yes
votesFunny: there is often more than one route to the "map exit" you have to protect
commentsCount: sometimes even multiple exits... You also get a hero
column16: and unlock new heroes as you continue. You'll have to decide which hero you need for a specific level
column17: as they all have different skills.\n\nThis game also has a very hefty "skill tree" that can mean the difference between life and death. To unlock these bonuses you have to collect stars. Each level has a capability of providing you with 3 stars and you lose stars based on how many enemies make it past your defenses. This will bring you to
column19: have to go back and clean up earlier levels. Some will argue that this is a bad thing. I argue that it's actually a good thing. First
column20: when you take on those earlier levels again you do so with your upgrades intact
column22: it allows you to take a break from not being able to beat your current level
column23: so you don't consider "rage quitting". Third
column24: it allows you to gain more stars so you can unlock more abilities and then decimate that level you were just getting ticked off at. Proper leveling can really make a difference on the game's overall difficulty.\n\nThe music for the game is pretty repetitive
column25: with each level having virtually the same music to it. That said
column26: it doesn't get annoying in the least. It's pretty much background sound
column30: and bomb exploding takes center stage in the audio department. Sound is very well handled
column31: and I like the fact that there is a bit of voice added to the characters as well.\n\nI was going to give Kingdom Rush a 9/10
column32: but I think I need to up the scale because I feel it's more like 99/100. Why did it lose a point? Well
column33: I felt sometimes you didn't get enough money from kills to have the upgrades you needed to defeat the level. You're constantly going
column34: "Dammit if I could have only upgraded that tower once more I would have stopped that last guy!" That said
column35: it's all part of the challenge
column36: and this game is a challenge.\n\nIf you like classic Tower Defense games

reviewText:
I've played Kingdom Rush Frontiers on ArmorGames.com and immediately got hooked. When I saw there was a full game on Steam for a low price? I immediately bought it and now I'm halfway through it! I was no fan of tower defenses (literal towers and lanes, not Plants vs Zombies, please) until I tried Ironhide Studio's Kingdom Rush!! If you want REAL tower defense, get THIS game. It is full of content, full of  different characters and towers to try out, placement, upgrades and strategy actually COUNT in this game. It IS simple, but it won't baby you and you won't need babying but it DOES have reasonable challenges. Get this game!! And try the game on ArmorGames, it is significantly different than this game here somehow, but I have no complaints.

HOWEVER, and I don't know if only I'm the one experiencing it, but the Steam version of Kingdom Rush has its...bugs. On the technical side sometimes out-of-stage music plays alongside the in-stage music, and if I didn't pause and unpause the game, the introduction of a new tower I just unlocked won't show up and I cannot continue the game as the stage is unclickable.

It sometime also has some visual bugs. There's random imagery fidgeting around the top right of the map selection screen. And somehow every time I quit to the main menu, it either has loads of Kingdom Rush logos splashed across a screen of black or just a black screen (the buttons of the main menu can still be clicked though, but of course I don't know which is which.)

These happen sometimes and not all of the times. I'll reinstall for the 3rd time later, so I am not sure if I am just tad unlucky on getting corrupted files, or it is really a bug. With all that said, KUDOS to Ironhide Game Studio. Thankyou for your work!!

Again, I feel that tower defence has had its day in the sun, and that's the only thing that kept me from being a fan of this game.\n\nIf you're NOT tired of tower defence game, this is definitely worth playing.

reviewText: This is a fantastic tower defense game. The art and animations are reminiscent of something from The Behemoth, the sound is appropriate to the style, and the game play is incredibly smooth. Even at full price, this is well worth the cost of admission. It's got a lot of content packed into that $10 price tag. Note that this is NOT infected with the micro-transaction, money-grab nonsense that ruined the mobile versions. Everything is included in the initial price and the game is infinitely better for it.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Kingdom Rush is, without a doubt, the second best classic-style Tower Defense game out there. The first being the Defense Grid series, of course. That said, if you own Defense Grid (or not) you deserve to give Kingdom Rush a chance anyway.\n\nStarting out as a portable game on iOS and Android, I half expected the PC version to just be a cheap port. Oh man was I wrong! Graphics are subtly improved, while not loosing their style. The map view is way better on the PC version. The difficulty has been upped, to force you to plan better. Even mouse effects have been added when you're casting your fireball" and "reinforce" skills. The game actually feels as if it was made for the PC
date: and that's how game ports should be!\n\nThe graphics for Kingdom Rush are different and unique. You'll absolutely love them. The tower upgrades are also VERY well done
recommended: with each upgrade changing both the look of the "tower" and the "units" it supports. While not really that dissimilar from the portable version
hoursPlayed: it does make viewing the game on 24+ inch screens a delightful experience.\n\nGamev play is the biggest surprise here
voteText: because this isn't any ordinary tower defense game. There's also a bit of RTS involved. For example
helpfulPercent: when you put down a "soldier" tower (which spawns 3 soldiers) you can set a relay flag within the radius of the tower's influence. This allows you to put many towers in close proximity
votesHelpful: rallying them at the same spot to form an army
votesTotal: or have your tower in the vicinity of multiple paths so you can adjust your raly deployments to whichever path needs it at the time. Yes
votesFunny: there is often more than one route to the "map exit" you have to protect
commentsCount: sometimes even multiple exits... You also get a hero
column16: and unlock new heroes as you continue. You'll have to decide which hero you need for a specific level
column17: as they all have different skills.\n\nThis game also has a very hefty "skill tree" that can mean the difference between life and death. To unlock these bonuses you have to collect stars. Each level has a capability of providing you with 3 stars and you lose stars based on how many enemies make it past your defenses. This will bring you to
column19: have to go back and clean up earlier levels. Some will argue that this is a bad thing. I argue that it's actually a good thing. First
column20: when you take on those earlier levels again you do so with your upgrades intact
column22: it allows you to take a break from not being able to beat your current level
column23: so you don't consider "rage quitting". Third
column24: it allows you to gain more stars so you can unlock more abilities and then decimate that level you were just getting ticked off at. Proper leveling can really make a difference on the game's overall difficulty.\n\nThe music for the game is pretty repetitive
column25: with each level having virtually the same music to it. That said
column26: it doesn't get annoying in the least. It's pretty much background sound
column30: and bomb exploding takes center stage in the audio department. Sound is very well handled
column31: and I like the fact that there is a bit of voice added to the characters as well.\n\nI was going to give Kingdom Rush a 9/10
column32: but I think I need to up the scale because I feel it's more like 99/100. Why did it lose a point? Well
column33: I felt sometimes you didn't get enough money from kills to have the upgrades you needed to defeat the level. You're constantly going
column34: "Dammit if I could have only upgraded that tower once more I would have stopped that last guy!" That said
column35: it's all part of the challenge
column36: and this game is a challenge.\n\nIf you like classic Tower Defense games
column37: this is one you have to own. It will frustrate the hell out of you
column38: it will bring you a lot of satisfaction
column39:
and It's well worth the $10.




* My review is based on my 30+ years of gaming experience
column40: my vast experience with other games like this one
column41: and my experiences with this game on both Android and PC.  Constructive criticism is encouraged
column42: however if your comment is based solely on the fact you can’t beat this game then I suggest you move along as you won’t find sympathy here."

reviewText:
I've played Kingdom Rush Frontiers on ArmorGames.com and immediately got hooked. When I saw there was a full game on Steam for a low price? I immediately bought it and now I'm halfway through it! I was no fan of tower defenses (literal towers and lanes, not Plants vs Zombies, please) until I tried Ironhide Studio's Kingdom Rush!! If you want REAL tower defense, get THIS game. It is full of content, full of  different characters and towers to try out, placement, upgrades and strategy actually COUNT in this game. It IS simple, but it won't baby you and you won't need babying but it DOES have reasonable challenges. Get this game!! And try the game on ArmorGames, it is significantly different than this game here somehow, but I have no complaints.

HOWEVER, and I don't know if only I'm the one experiencing it, but the Steam version of Kingdom Rush has its...bugs. On the technical side sometimes out-of-stage music plays alongside the in-stage music, and if I didn't pause and unpause the game, the introduction of a new tower I just unlocked won't show up and I cannot continue the game as the stage is unclickable.

It sometime also has some visual bugs. There's random imagery fidgeting around the top right of the map selection screen. And somehow every time I quit to the main menu, it either has loads of Kingdom Rush logos splashed across a screen of black or just a black screen (the buttons of the main menu can still be clicked though, but of course I don't know which is which.)

These happen sometimes and not all of the times. I'll reinstall for the 3rd time later, so I am not sure if I am just tad unlucky on getting corrupted files, or it is really a bug. With all that said, KUDOS to Ironhide Game Studio. Thankyou for your work!!

reviewText: A fun and addictive tower defense game with it's own twist to the genre. The gameplay is logical, polished and goodlooking, with a few funny quirks hidden around the game here and there to give you random snorts of humour. The main power of it is the adorably funny comic-style graphics that distinguish this as a better game than one of it's many tower-defense rivals. enough gameplay and bonus missions to keep you busy for hours, and fun achievements that are worth getting. A definite recommendation. Fortunately, it is even better than the original mobile game. Kudos to the developers.

reviewText:
Okay, the game isnt complex, but its the most fun I had for less than £3! I wont bore you with the gameplay but basically you use three keys to play the game and you then die in lava. But you then get to upgrade and then try again. Then die in lava. But then upgrade some more and try again and get even further than last time and then you die in lava. Then you upgrade and you try again etc...
I intended to only spend half an hour playing this game before hitting the hay. I looked at the time 30mins later only to find that TWO HOURS had passed!
Any game that can make you lose your track of time because you are enjoying it gets a great big thumbs up from me! Highly Recommended little game.
Just make sure to keep an eye on the clock. Its so easy to say one more try...""
